title: What was the worst year to buy a PC, and why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Said in jest: The worst year to buy a PC was…. ANY year I bought a PC. You see I started young, and the industry was young too. So after starting with a Sinclair and then the VIC20, C64, and gawds SX64, I started looking at Amigas. A year or so later PC games started coming into their own and the PC wasn’t a business inventory, sales management, personnel database only device, it could actually be fun. And Amiga… well, that’s history folks… so… Now I have the suite of Microsoft tablet pcs and the Studio all in one. They, of course, by now, are becoming dated. So, there’s a company out there who ‘rents’ remote workstation configurations located in server farms and have a direct connection to high-density fiber trunks. They can update storage, cores, memory, and bandpass on-demand. I may have solved my PC purchasing curse, but I think I’ve fallen deep into the rabbit hole. YMMV, good luck! :)

2008 Because just about every PC on the shelf of your local electronics store came with Windows Vista. I bought one Lenovo laptop that year using my IBM employee discount. Every time I opened the screen it took 10 minutes before I could do anything useful. Spent about a month trying to fix the problems and gave up. Tried installing XP and Microsoft didn’t see my point of view in installing an older version of the OS. Fortunately “format c:” works quite well if booting from an alternate device. That laptop has gone to the electronics graveyard in my garage, but still own a 2009 desktop running Linux without any problems.

Every year is the worst year to buy a PC, newer, faster machines are always coming in a few months time and your shiny new machine will be considered old hat, or even obsolete. Just look at all those people who forked out for a 2080 in 2020, only for NVidea to announce a much more powerful 3080 for nearly half the money a few months later.
